H0.text: Who flew a kite in a storm on June 15, 1750, proving that lightning was electrical. Benjamin Franklin

H1.text: Who flew a kite in a storm on June 15, 1750, proving that lightning was electrical. Alessandro Volta

H2.text: Who flew a kite in a storm on June 15, 1750, proving that lightning was electrical. Michael Faraday

H3.text: Who flew a kite in a storm on June 15, 1750, proving that lightning was electrical. Franklinic

A4.text: On June 15, 1752, Franklin may possibly have conducted his well‑known kite experiment in Philadelphia.

A5.text: He used the kite to collect some electric charge from a storm cloud, showing that lightning was electrical.

A6.text: Benjamin Franklin 300 (1706–2006) Archived August 20, 2008, at the Wayback Machine Official web site of the Benjamin Franklin Tercentenary.

A7.text: The Historical Society of Pennsylvania Collection of Benjamin Franklin Papers, including correspondence, government documents, writings and a copy of his will, are available for research use at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

A8.text: Electric discharge is the release and transmission of electricity in a gas.
